{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3322254,"name":"Rene Mercer","username":"rmercer","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/eb9ed0/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-02T22:57:26.703Z","cooked":"

Hi All,
Sorry for the beginner question, we dont have a huge amount of electrical experience in the team.
Our team is looking at using the AB RightSight (42EF-D2MPAK-F4) sensor from FIRST choice. I have come across a couple of posts regarding the need to reduce the voltage of the sensor down to 5V before connecting to the DIO input on the roborio. I have read the post here here but also the diagram from FIRST shows direct wiring of a photoelectric sensor to the DIO of the roborio 2.0 without a voltage reduction Here.
Anyway - assuming it does need to be reduced - i am looking at a neat and easy way to do this. Does anyone know if this option would work for this? 2 Channel level converter
Specifically i am planning to follow this wiring diagram

image1464×1023 198 KB

Thanks for any help

(beginner)","clicks":12},{"url":"https://docs.wpilib.org/en/stable/_images/frc-control-system-layout-rev.svg","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"frc-control-system-layout-rev.svg","clicks":9},{"url":"https://wiki.dfrobot.com/2_Channel_Level_Converter_12V_to_5V_SKU_DFR0912","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"12 to 5V 2-Channel Level Converter / Shifter Wiki - DFRobot","clicks":5},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/a/d/ad103b167edb414d08c5acc7e7b6cdf360030de8.png","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":37769,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/wiring-the-first-choice-photoelectric-sensor-rightsight-42ef-d2mpak-f4/456991/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3322258,"name":"Tauseef Afraz","username":"TFM110","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tfm110/{size}/197758_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-02T23:05:07.829Z","cooked":"

What you can do is wire the positive and negative to the PDH/PDP/MPM or the VRM 12V500mA port then the signal wire to the DIO port on the RIO.

rmercer:

Does anyone know if this option would work for this? 2 Channel level converter

This would not work as the input is 12V, not the output. The output is 5V.

Hi,
Thanks for the reply Are you sure this is OK? - It was how i was originally planning on wiring the sensor, 12V from a VRM and then just the signal wire to the roborio DIO input until i came across the post above. Apparently the output signal voltage from the sensor is 12V? According to the robioro information the max input on the DIO is 5.25V https://www.ni.com/docs/en-US/bundle/roborio-frc-specs/page/specs.html#page=3
Hence the dilema…

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2024-03-03T11:38:08.408Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":88,"readers_count":87,"score":42.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":456991,"topic_slug":"wiring-the-first-choice-photoelectric-sensor-rightsight-42ef-d2mpak-f4","display_username":"Rene Mercer","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":64610,"username":"mikej2700","name":"Mike Simons","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/bb73d2/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":37769,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/wiring-the-first-choice-photoelectric-sensor-rightsight-42ef-d2mpak-f4/456991/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3322500,"name":"Jon Stratis","username":"Jon_Stratis","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jon_stratis/{size}/2663_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-03T11:48:17.006Z","cooked":"

We are using these this year. Power into the 12V side of the VRM, and we implemented a voltage divider to bring the output down to 5V. Real easy to do, you just need two appropriately sized resistors.

In probing it without the voltage divider, we found that the low state was very much borderline on whether it would be low enough to trigger a state change on the DIO, while the high state was (obviously) way outside the proper range for the DIO port.

Anyways, with the voltage divider in place, it’s worked perfectly!

rmercer:

beginner question

Maybe a beginner question but you made a not a beginner observation that FIRST Choice is providing a totally inappropriate sensor for use with a roboRIO. That sensor is a PNP connection and the roboRIO as seen on the wiring diagram is for NPN connections. There have been similar and proper NPN sensors in KOP. I’m baffled why FIRST would accept a “wrong” donation and Andy Mark not correct them. It isn’t worth it when the right style is readily available.

This is just what’s worked for us, reading some other posts, it might be wrong, so I would probably look at running it off of the VRM instead, or try the voltage dividers and just use the signal on the rio

Now i know that - do you think this 12V to 5V converter would acheive the same outcome? Im just looking for a more foolproof solution for the electronics team.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2024-03-04T02:27:44.663Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":67,"readers_count":66,"score":23.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":456991,"topic_slug":"wiring-the-first-choice-photoelectric-sensor-rightsight-42ef-d2mpak-f4","display_username":"Rene Mercer","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":24594,"username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":37769,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/wiring-the-first-choice-photoelectric-sensor-rightsight-42ef-d2mpak-f4/456991/11","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3322994,"name":"Jon Stratis","username":"Jon_Stratis","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jon_stratis/{size}/2663_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-04T02:59:41.676Z","cooked":"

Yes, that’s very similar to what we have. Note that the resistors you marked will only step it down to 6V, not 5V. To truly get it to 5V, you need R1 to be 1.4x as big as R2 - for example, R1 at 14k and R2 at 10k steps down the 12V high to a 5V high. Per our measurements, the sensor had somewhere around 1.6V low, and the RoboRio specs require 0.0-0.8V (and note that the high side requires 2.0V-5.25V). If you go with 10k and 10k, that ~1.6V will end up ~0.8V, which may or may not be reliable. If you go with 14k/10k, then it drops down to ~0.667V, which should be much more reliable for you (it’s been 100% for us!). There are plenty of voltage divider calculators out there, if you’re struggling to find a good pair of resistors - in this case, I think it’s better to go a little bigger on R1 and overshoot the step down than it is to undershoot it.

Once again thanks for the help!
